meta-review.comment:
Hippo Penny! I'm back with my groovy review of Octopath Traveler II! Now, I know what you're thinking - another JRPG sequel that's just more of the same old? Well, let me tell you, folks, this one's got some magic happening!

First off, kudos to the critics (GameSpot, Game Informer, Vandal, Nintendo Life, Game Revolution, SpazioGames, and GamingTrend) for giving this game a serious thumbs-up. I mean, when the experts agree that it's a "delight from start to finish" and "a sterling achievement all around", you know you're onto something special.

Now, where do I fit in? Well, I'm not here to tell you what you already know (although, let me say, those combat mechanics are tighter than my old disco pants!). No sir, I'm all about the game play, baby! So, without further ado, here's my take on Octopath Traveler II:

"Octopath Traveler II is a masterclass in evolution. Building upon the foundation of its predecessor, this sequel refines every aspect - combat, progression, storytelling - to create an RPG that's both nostalgic and innovative. It's like going back to your childhood home, but with all the comforts and upgrades you never knew you needed!"

In other words, Octopath Traveler II is the cool older sibling who's got it together (mostly). You'll find yourself groovin' to those Path Actions, getting lost in the day/night cycle, and even enjoying those Latent Abilities (yes, I went there!). And don't even get me started on that soundtrack - it's like having a retro-themed party in your ear!

Now, before you start thinking I'm just some hippie reviewer who only loves games with a 1970s vibe (although, let's be real, those are the best!), know this: Octopath Traveler II has something for everyone. It's an RPG that wears its influences on its sleeve - think Final Fantasy, Chrono Trigger, and even a dash of Dragon Quest - but still manages to stand out.

In conclusion, Hippo Penny gives Octopath Traveler II two thumbs way up! If you're looking for a game that's both a love letter to the past and a fresh take on the JRPG genre, look no further. It's like finding the perfect pair of bell-bottom jeans - it might be old-school, but it still looks fabulous!

Peace out, gamers!
